jdm.name: Twitter
jdm.notes: Your account is actually 'deactivated' before being deleted. Only after 30 days of remaining deactivated will it then be deleted. More details

points.title: Terms may be changed at any time, sometimes with very little advance notice

tosdr.tldr: This service may change the terms at any time, but in the past notice has been given to users only hours ahead of the change being implemented. Notification is given via their site or in some cases, via an @Twitter update or email. Your continued use of the service is taken as acceptance of the new or changed terms.

topics.description: The terms are a contract between two parties, and it should not be changed unilaterally without consultation of the other party. Services should listen to what their users say and care about, and give them a vote in each substantial change.

tosdr.tldr: Twitter discloses their use of session cookies and persistent cookies. However much of the service, like searching or looking at public profiles or lists, does not rely on cookies to work. Acceptance of cookies can be controlled by you by adjusting your browser settings.

topics.description: Cookies are files stored locally in your web browser containing identifiable information.

tosdr.case: tracking data deleted after 10 days and opt-out
tosdr.tldr: Twitter begins deleting all tracking data it collects from you after 10 days. You can also opt-out of personalisation settings which track your website visits to tailor their service to you. To completely opt-out, enable the Do-Not-Track option in your browser settings.

topics.description: The terms sometimes describe the level of logging and the level of data collection and which kinds of data the service is processing. Anonymity or the right to use a pseudonym can be very important for freedom of expression (e.g. for people exercising a certain profession, or people living in authoritarian regimes).

points.title: A public record of past terms of service policies

tosdr.tldr: The terms of service page on their site provides a link to their archive of all past policies so you can see how terms have changed with each update.

points.title: Twitter deletes data after 30 days. It keeps rights on your content.

tosdr.tldr: If you deactivate your account or your account is closed, Twitter retains all the rights on your content due to their very broad copyright licence which applies even after termination of the service. However, after 30 days Twitter begins to delete your data.

topics.description: Once you subscribe to the service, will you have the right to leave it and remove your data?

points.title: Promise to inform you about data requests from governments

tosdr.tldr: This service informs users when their data is sought by the government, unless prohibited by law. With this knowledge, you have an opportunity to involve yourself if you think the request is unreasonable.

points.title: Very broad copyright license on your content

tosdr.tldr: The copyright licence is very broad. It includes the right for Twitter to share your tweets and any attached content like images or video with others on their terms, not yours.

topics.description: Copyright law gives you control over how your content (texts, photos, videos, etc.) can be used, by whom they can be distributed, modified, etc. Sometimes, online services need your permission to perform certain tasks with your content. That's why they ask you to grant them a copyright license. But sometimes, the copyright license is so broad, that your content can be exploited by others without asking you.
